alert.note: Alert for Orange; Rockland (New York) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS New York City - Upton (Long Island and New York City)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 3:42AM EST until January 12 at 2:30AM EST by NWS New York City - Upton
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in New Jersey...New York... Ramapo River near Mahwah affecting Orange, Bergen, Passaic and Rockland Counties. For the Ramapo River...including Mahwah...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY FRIDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Ramapo River near Mahwah. * WHEN...Until early Friday morning. * IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, State Route 202 floods downstream. Moderate flooding along Route 202 and Route 17. Water into backyards. Minor flooding along Brakeshoe Place, Brook Street and Catherine Avenue. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:30 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 9.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:30 AM EST Wednesday was 9.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 10.2 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 10.4 feet on 09/22/1938. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (1 am EST) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Sat Ramapo River Mahwah 8.0 9.7 Wed 2 am EST 9.7 7.7 6.7 &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 345 PM EST.
